originContent: # s3 - Efficient Yet Effective Search Agent Training via RL
***You Don't Need That Much Data to Train a Search Agent***

`s3` is a simple yet powerful framework for training search agents in retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). It teaches language models how to search more effectively‚Äîwithout changing the generator itself. By focusing solely on the search component, `s3` achieves strong performance across QA tasks with just a fraction of the data used by prior methods. It's modular, efficient, and designed to work seamlessly with any black-box LLM.
# install torch [or you can skip this step and let vllm to install the correct version for you]
translatedContent: # install torch [or you can skip this step and let vllm to install the correct version for you]

originContent: pip3 install vllm==0.6.3 # or you can install 0.5.4, 0.4.2 and 0.3.1
translatedContent: pip3 install vllm==0.6.3 # or you can install 0.5.4, 0.4.2 and 0.3.1

originContent: # we use pyserini for efficient retrieval and evaluation
translatedContent: # we use pyserini for efficient retrieval and evaluation

originContent: pip install pyserini    # the version we used is 0.22.1
translatedContent: pip install pyserini    # the version we used is 0.22.1

originContent: pip install wandb IPython matplotlib huggingface_hub
translatedContent: pip install wandb IPython matplotlib huggingface_hub

originContent: conda install pytorch==2.4.0 torchvision==0.19.0 torchaudio==2.4.0 pytorch-cuda=12.1 -c pytorch -c nvidia
translatedContent: conda install pytorch==2.4.0 torchvision==0.19.0 torchaudio==2.4.0 pytorch-cuda=12.1 -c pytorch -c nvidia

originContent: ***Precompute Na√Øve RAG Initialization*** (or you can download our processed data here: [huggingface](https://huggingface.co/datasets/pat-jj/s3_processed_data))
bash generator_llms/host.sh # modify tensor-parallel-size to the number of GPUs you use
translatedContent: bash generator_llms/host.sh # modify tensor-parallel-size to the number of GPUs you use

originContent: bash scripts/precompute.sh # this step will take a while, as it will precompute the na√Øve RAG Cache for training
translatedContent: bash scripts/precompute.sh # this step will take a while, as it will precompute the na√Øve RAG Cache for training

originContent: ***This step is for the training of S3***
***This step is for the context gathering of s3 / baselines***
bash scripts/baselines/deepretrieval.sh # run DeepRetrieval Query Rewriting + Retrieval
translatedContent: bash scripts/baselines/deepretrieval.sh # run DeepRetrieval Query Rewriting + Retrieval

originContent: ***This step is for the evaluation of s3 / baselines***

If you want to test s3 on your own corpus/dataset, you can refer to this commit to see what you need to do to build your own pipeline: [commit 8420538](https://github.com/pat-jj/s3/commit/8420538836febbe59d5bcbe41187f16908c9c36c)

Several developers have already reproduced our results successfully. If you have questions or run into issues, feel free to [open an issue](https://github.com/pat-jj/s3/issues) ‚Äî we‚Äôre happy to provide hands-on guidance (see [this example](https://github.com/pat-jj/s3/issues/20)).

Although reproducing the model yourself is straightforward ‚Äî and we actually **recommend training from scratch**, since evaluation is often much more time-consuming than training ‚Äî we also provide a reference checkpoint: [s3-8-3-3-20steps](https://huggingface.co/pat-jj/s3-8-3-3-20steps), trained in about one hour.
We would like to thank the following projects:
